description.narrative:
BACKGROUND Even though the number of domestic workers continues to grow globally, it remains a generally invisible form of employment in many countries. Under-valued and exploited, poorly regulated domestic workers mostly endure poor economic and socialconditions. South Africa is often cited as one of the most unequal countries in the world with domestic workers at the lower end of the foodchain. There are currently more than a million domestic workers in South Africa and although recognised as workers and covered by specific labour law, Sectoral Determination 7 for Domestic Workers, they remain one of the mostly poorly paid and disempowered sections of the workforce. A hard to organize sector, with weak organization exposes them to numerous vulnerabilities. On 31 March 2012 MsBadanile Maria Mahlangu – worker, mother, grandmother, sister, daughter – died tragically, by drowning in her employer’s swimming pool. At the time of death, she had been working for the same employer for 22 years. Because domestic workers are not covered under the Compensation for Occupational Injuries and Diseases Act (COIDA), Ms Mahlangu’s next of kin were not entitled to any benefits. Ms.Ms Pinky Mashiane, a representative of domestic workers, sought to pursue the matter and persevered tirelessly garnering support along the way. In 2018 a campaign was formed as a means of creating awareness about the Mahlangu case and advocating for inclusion of domestic workers in the Compensation for Occupational Injuries and Diseases Act (COIDA). At that stage there was no coherent channelfor domestic workers to defend their rights across different trade unions and organizations. There appeared to be little public knowledge on the challenges experienced by domestic workers and their limited access to justice. There also appeared to be very limitedcapacity – including digital literacy skills – among domestic workers to effectively spearhead campaigns advocating for their rights.
PROPOSED INTERVENTIONS The proposed interventions are aimed at strengthening the capability of domestic workers to self-organisein defence of their rights. In addition to ensuring a skilled and empowered workforce, the interventions seek to create a digitally enabling environment for domestic workersas a direct challenge to the super-exploitative on-demand labour platforms. Developmentalobjective: A skilled and empowered workforce in the domestic work sector, based on dignified work Medium to long-term: (1-2 years) • On-demand labour platforms uphold and protect worker rights • All employers of domestic workers uphold and protect worker rights •Domestic workers are mobilised and organised to demand their worker rights
Project objective: Capacitated domestic workers able toorganise digitally and build solidarity
Specific objectives: 1. co-ordinated communication and action 2. skilled worker leaders 3.improved organisation of domestic workers 4. increased voice of domestic workers

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam South Africa is an independent Oxfam affiliate who manages and implements the programme of Oxfam in South Africa. Its programme prioritises vulnerable communities and creating lasting change in, and for all the people in South Africa. Oxfam South Africa works in partnership with organisations who seek to create meaningful and sustainable change that benefits vulnerable groups in South Africa through the attainment, protection and preservation of human rights and social justice. The country program will continue to focus its work through ‘active citizenship and accountability’ and ‘gender justice’ lenses.
